gaps.name: Subject-Object Separation
gaps.description: Language structures that force a distinction between perceiver and perceived, preventing expression of non-dual states of awareness.

gaps.name: Linear Temporality
gaps.description: Grammatical structures that enforce sequential time relationships, preventing expression of non-linear temporal experiences.
examples: Before attending the meeting, she prepared notes
After the storm, the sky cleared
While eating, he read the newspaper

gaps.name: Unidirectional Causality
gaps.description: Linguistic patterns that enforce one-way cause-effect relationships, limiting expression of mutual or circular causation.
examples: The heat caused the water to boil
Her decision led to significant changes

gaps.name: Binary Logic
gaps.description: Logical structures that enforce true/false distinctions, preventing expression of multi-valued logical states.
examples: Either it's raining or it's not raining
The statement is either true or false
You're either with us or against us

gaps.name: Single Perspective
gaps.description: Narrative structures that enforce a single point of view, limiting expression of multi-perspective awareness.
examples: From my perspective, the policy is flawed
In her view, the situation was improving
I believe this approach is correct

gaps.name: Entity Persistence
gaps.description: Language structures that enforce stable identities across time, limiting expression of processual reality.

gaps.name: Spatial Containment
gaps.description: Conceptual structures that enforce clear boundaries between inside and outside, limiting expression of interpenetration.
examples: The book is in the box

gaps.name: Property Attribution
gaps.description: Linguistic patterns that enforce properties as belonging to substances, limiting expression of relationality.

gaps.name: Intentional Agency
gaps.description: Grammatical structures that enforce clear agent-action relationships, limiting expression of distributed causation.

gaps.name: Emotional Categorization
gaps.description: Lexical limitations that enforce discrete emotion categories, limiting expression of emotional complexity.
